title: David Love In The Countryside on his secret relationship before coming out
text:
On tonight’s show David Busby reveals how long it took him to come out to his parents (Picture: BBC Two)

A dairy farmer who will feature on BBC Two’s Love In The Countryside tonight has told of the moment he ‘came out’ to his parents.

David Busby from Cumbria is the only gay farmer on the BBC Two programme and ahead of tonight’s show he has exclusively revealed to Metro.co.uk that he didn’t ‘come out’ to his family until he was 28-years-old and that he kept his relationship a secret for six months.

We first met David last week where he went to London for a round of speed dates with a bunch of admirers – and on tonight’s episode the dairy farmer introduces his potential suitors to life on the farm.

‘It was tricky coming out to my parents so I kept my relationship a secret for six months,’ he said.

‘I have had girlfriends in the past, and I thought I was gay but I tried to avoid it for a long time. It wasn’t until I was definitely sure that I decided to come out.

‘It got to the stage where I had to tell people about it, it wasn’t an easy thing to do but the support I have had from my family and friends has been amazing.

‘I think the reason I found it so scary is that because I am a farmer, I am last in line to carry on the Bushby name and so it’s a lot of pressure on me.’

The 35-year-old, who has been single for 18 months, is looking for a male partner to share his agricultural life with, although David admitted that he struggled to get back into the dating game after his seven year relationship ended abruptly.

He added: ‘I was in a relationship for seven years and one day he just left me, I got home to a note on the door.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I have found it difficult to adjust to single life and get back in the dating scene, plus I live right on the coast so it’s so hard to meet someone.

David Bushby goes on three dates to decide who he wants to be with (Picture: BBC)

‘The population is really low and finding someone who is suitable is a challenge. I went on a dating app and I found myself extending the distance and it just got ridiculous – and that’s when I applied for the show.

‘I honestly didn’t think I would find anyone on the show, but it was a confidence thing and to make me see there are people out there and I’m not on my own.’

Farming wasn’t always the life for David as he attended Bristol University where he studied a degree in Geography.

David said he didn’t ‘come out’ to his parents until he was 28-years-old (Picture: BBC)

Although, after moving to Nottingham for two years he soon realised the hustle and bustle wasn’t for him so he retreated back to his parent’s farm – where he has been for the past 11 years.

Tuesday night’s show will follow David on his three dates with his potential suitors, Michael, Sal and Luke.

David said: ‘It was really great having them come to the farm but it was a bit weird as they all stayed in my house and I went to stay with my parents.

‘They were all completely different, one was scared of animals, another came from central London and the other one has horses so he had a bit of a agricultural background.

Advertisement

‘They got to milk the cows, have a tour of the farm and then I got to go on a date with each of them which was nice. We went rowing, to the pub and the beach.’

David Bushy said he struggled to date after his relationship ended (Picture: BBC)

After his dates, the dairy farmer admitted he got emotional trying to whittle it down to one person.

‘My friends helped me make the decision as they also got to meet each of them,’ he said.

‘It was such a tough decision as I spent such little time with them and during that time I wanted to be the best version of myself, towards the end it got draining.

‘I found that I did click with two of my dates, and tonight you will see how I get upset in my decision making so I am not sure how it’s going to look on camera.

‘Next week you will get to see who I pick, but the whole experience was so much fun, I had the time of my life.’

Love In The Countryside airs tonight at 9pm on BBC Two.
